titleStmt.title: Investigation of the structure of ironcarbide/iron-oxide core-shell nanoparticles with additional carbon shells for magnetic hyperthermia

analytic.title: Investigation of the structure of ironcarbide/iron-oxide core-shell nanoparticles with additional carbon shells for magnetic hyperthermia

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

div.head: Report:
div.p: The two series of iron/iron oxide (R-samples) and iron/iron carbide (A-samples) nanopartilces with additional carbon shell were synthesized and studied by XAS (XANES and EXAFS) experiemnts at BM23. The variation of conditions of pyrolysis should allow to vary the ratio of iron oxide (carbide) and metal iron in the nanoparticles. Indeed, the spectra show distinguishable differencies between samples, as it illustrated on Figures 1 and 2. However, the changes are not monotonic. The fourier-transforms of EXAFS functions are not monotonicaly either, but this can be caused by interference between contributions from different states of iron. The evidence can be shown by simple FT analysis of EXAFS using two scattering contribtions Fe-light atom (O or C) and Fe-Fe presented in Tables 1 and 2. Experiment title: Investigation of the structure of ironcarbide/iron-oxide core-shell nanoparticles with additional carbon shells for magnetic hyperthermia Experiment number: MD-1068 Figure 2. Measured experimental spectra of iron/iron carbide (A-samples) nanoparticles.

Table 1. Results of fitting of EXAFS of iron/iron oxide nanoparticles by two shell fit model Sample N(Fe-O) R(Fe-O) σ 2 (Fe-O) N(Fe-Fe) R(Fe-Fe) σ 2 (Fe-Fe) χ υ 2 R1 (Fe/C) 1.0 1.84 0.0040 7.4 2.45 0.0078 600 R3 1.3 1.81 0.0040 4.3 2.42 0.0047 100 R4 2.3 2.01 0.0084 5.1 2.58 0.0040 700 R5 3.7 3.2 0.0040 3.7 2.62 0.0063 60 R2* (Fe 2 O 3 /C) 5.1 1.92 0.0130 5.1 2.49 0.0040 200 The poor overall fitting quality indicates on the insufficience of used two shell fit model. This model should be improvaed by addition of more distant coordination shells of structures of bulk iron, iron oxide and iron carbides. Nevertheless, the results for the samples R1, R3, A70 and A71 shows their similarity to pure iron nanoparticle, as it was supposed by synthesis. Other samples, obtained as a result of more intensive pyrolisis, demonstrate more complex local atomic structure, which can be understood using more detailed model and using application of complimentary theoretical and experimental techniques.
